newsitem.title: RUSSIA: FedEx lowers its rates from Russia.
newsitem.headline: FedEx lowers its rates from Russia.

text.p: U.S. courier Federal Express has lowered its rates from Russia to all destinations worldwide, the company's Moscow office said on Monday.
The cost of sending a 500-gram (1.1-lb) letter from Moscow to North or South America was lowered to $38 from $65, the Memphis-based company said in a statement.
It will now also cost $38 to send a letter of the same weight to many destinations in Western Europe, down from $60, and to Eastern Europe, which previously cost $65.

"Our new tariff offers substantial savings to international express shippers, who expect top quality service for the most competitive price," Petra Rittersberger, FedEx marketing manager for Central and Eastern Europe, said in a statement.
FedEx competes with a number of foreign companies, -- including DHL, TNT and United Parcel Service -- in Russia, where the local mail system has a poor reputation for reliability.
The FedEx rate reduction also applied to heavier packages.
FedEx senior vice-president David Bronczek said his company had invested about $16 million expanding its operations in Russia.
Last year FedEx began daily cargo service from Moscow's Vnukovo airport to Paris via Frankfurt operating a Boeing 727-200 jet.
